title: H. Donl Peterson
text:
Harry Donl Peterson (February 17, 1930 – March 21, 1994) was a religion professor at <a href="Brigham%20Young%20University">Brigham Young University</a> (BYU) who primarily studied topics related to the <a href="Book%20of%20Mormon">Book of Mormon</a> and <a href="Pearl%20of%20Great%20Price%20%28Mormonism%29">Pearl of Great Price</a>.
Biography.
Peterson was born and raised in <a href="Lehi%2C%20Utah">Lehi, Utah</a>. He served a <a href="Missionary%20%28LDS%20Church%29">mission</a> in the <a href="Western%20United%20States">Western States</a> <a href="Mission%20%28LDS%20Church%29">Mission</a> (headquartered in <a href="Denver%2C%20Colorado">Denver, Colorado</a>). Peterson received his bachelor's and master's degrees from BYU. He also had a doctorate in education from <a href="Washington%20State%20University">Washington State University</a>. Starting in 1964 he was a professor at BYU. Prior to that he worked as a <a href="LDS%20Seminary">seminary</a> and <a href="Institute%20of%20Religion">institute</a> teacher and administrator with the <a href="Church%20Educational%20System">Church Educational System</a>. At BYU he directed several travel study programs as well as being involved with the <a href="Know%20Your%20Religion">Know Your Religion</a> program.
In <a href="The%20Church%20of%20Jesus%20Christ%20of%20Latter-day%20Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints</a> (LDS Church), Peterson served three times as a <a href="Bishop%20%28LDS%20Church%29">bishop</a> and was also <a href="Stake%20president">president</a> of the BYU 15th <a href="Stake%20%28LDS%20Church%29">Stake</a>. He served in the original <a href="branch%20presidency">branch presidency</a> of the <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> <a href="Branch%20%28LDS%20Church%29">Branch</a>.
Peterson married Mary Lou Schenk in the <a href="Salt%20Lake%20Temple">Salt Lake Temple</a> in 1953. They had six children.
At the age of 64, Peterson died of <a href="cancer">cancer</a> at his home in <a href="Orem%2C%20Utah">Orem, Utah</a>, and was buried in the Orem City Cemetery.
Publications.
In addition to his own attributed publications, Peterson also served on LDS Church writing committees that prepared four manuals for the church's <a href="Gospel%20Doctrine">Gospel Doctrine</a> classes.
